title: Angels News: Reid Detmers Shares His Game Plan Against Shohei Ohtani
text:
By William Frost ,
1 hour ago
Reid Detmers made a strong return to the major leagues, showcasing his skills against the Los Angeles Dodgers after a three-month stint in Triple-A. The left-handed pitcher, who had struggled earlier in the season with a 6.14 ERA, limited the Dodgers to just two earned runs over six innings, striking out ten batters and allowing only three hits.
Detmers faced a challenging top of the Dodgers' lineup in the third inning, where he surrendered both runs during a brief stretch. However, he quickly regained his composure, retiring the last 11 batters he faced and demonstrating the effectiveness of his revamped slider, which produced a 42% swing-and-miss rate.
“I’m glad to be back,” Detmers said . “It’s been a long three months. It was all worth it. The first innings my legs were a little shaky. I wasn’t nervous. It’s just a lot of adrenaline. I’m just happy to be back be a part of this club and just help us win some games.”
Manager Ron Washington praised Detmers for his improved command and ability to mix pitches effectively, particularly highlighting his use of off-speed pitches to keep hitters off-balance.
“Outstanding,” Washington said of Detmers . “The best command I’ve seen him have with his fastball. And you know, he was able to use his offspeed pitches in some very good situations. That got them off-balance, especially his changeup.”
Detmers had a specific strategy in mind for facing his former teammate, Shohei Ohtani, focusing on changing speeds and keeping the ball away.
"Just stay away, really," Detmers said . "Keep changing eye levels, keep changing speeds. I wasn’t trying to do anything crazy, just trying to let him get himself out.”
Ohtani finished the night with one hit, a triple, while also scoring two runs and striking out once. Overall, the Angels' pitching staff proved effective, with eight Dodgers striking out at least once during the game.
Related: Angels News: Ron Washington Justifies Intentionally Walking Shohei Ohtani
After Detmers' solid outing, the Angels turned to their bullpen to finish the game, but only one reliever allowed more than one hit. Detmers' performance has likely secured him another chance to remain in the starting rotation as the season progresses.
